cleaned_text: Acupuncture for arthritis? Acupuncture, a form of traditional Chinese medicine, has been used for centuries to treat a variety of conditions, including knee osteoarthritis. In recent years, acupuncture has gained popularity as an alternative treatment option for knee arthritis, as it is believed to be a safe and effective way to reduce pain and improve function. Knee osteoarthritis is a degenerative condition that occurs when the cartilage that cushions the bones in the knee joint wears away. This can lead to pain, stiffness, and difficulty moving the knee. Traditional treatment options for knee osteoarthritis include medications, physical therapy, weight management, bracing or orthotics, injections, and surgery. However, many patients are looking for alternative treatments such as acupuncture to manage their symptoms. Acupuncture involves the insertion of thin needles into specific points on the body, known as acupoints. The practitioner may also use heat, pressure, or electrical stimulation to enhance the effects of the needles. The goal of acupuncture is to restore balance and harmony to the body's energy flow, known as Qi (pronounced "chee"). Acupuncture has been found to be effective in treating knee osteoarthritis. A systematic review of randomized controlled trials published in the Journal of the American Medical Association (JAMA) found that acupuncture was more effective than sham (fake) acupuncture and had similar effects as physical therapy in reducing pain and improving function in patients with knee osteoarthritis. Another study published in the Journal of Rheumatology found that acupuncture was effective in reducing pain, improving function, and reducing the need for pain medication in patients with knee osteoarthritis. In addition to reducing pain and improving function, acupuncture may also have anti-inflammatory effects. A study published in the Journal of Traditional Chinese Medicine found that acupuncture reduced the levels of inflammatory markers in the blood of patients with knee osteoarthritis. It is important to note that while acupuncture may be an effective treatment option for knee osteoarthritis, it should not be used as a substitute for conventional treatments. Patients should consult with their healthcare provider to determine the best treatment plan for their individual needs. In conclusion, acupuncture is an effective alternative treatment option for knee osteoarthritis that can help reduce pain and improve function. It has been found to be more effective than sham acupuncture and has similar effects as physical therapy. Additionally, it may have anti-inflammatory effects. However, it should not be used as a substitute for conventional treatments and patients should consult their healthcare provider to determine the best treatment plan for their individual needs.
